content.description: Same start as Lighting the Torch. Traverse right under a shallow roof using the prominent horizontal crack for protection. Climb to the prow with airy exposure and surmount the lip, establishing on the Torch just left of Torched. Descend from the anchors on top of Lighting. The airy feel and the traverse made me think of the terrible space-based James Bond movie, "Moonraker".
content.protection: Small to medium cams up to 3 inches.
content.location: See route map, same start as "Lighting."

content.description:
This is a generally easy climb on solid rock that is a fun way to access the base of the Torch. It is also possible to do this route and connect directly to Torched to do the two routes in one pitch. Use long runners if attempting this. Named after the James Bond, "Goldfinger". 

  Hardest move is protected by the bolt at the base. The climb is on good rock that protects well and enables a nice warm-up climb to get to the base of the Torch. There are anchors here that can be used to establish for the three southern climbs up the Torch: Lighting, Torchraker, and Torched.
content.location: On the east side of the Torch, begins at the base of the lower wall. See route map.

climbs.name: Torched
climbs.fa: David Sampson, Arjun Heimsath and Catherine Conner

content.description: This torch climb ascends the East facing fin of the structure, following the steep line past one bolt to the top of the Torch. Small to medium cams. There are anchors at the top of this climb, but you can also use those for Lighting... Descend from Lighting .. anchors.
content.protection: Single bolt, a few medium cams.
content.location: See route map. East face of The Torch.

content.description: The right vertical crack (closest to the Torch) on the uppermost east-facing wall. Access the base of the wall from the scramble up towards the base of the Torch from the south. Getting on top enables a close view of the torch. Rap from anchors near the top of Periscope. Good trad practice.
content.location: See map, just to the right of Periscope.

content.description: The wonderful, broken north-facing rock of the bulge in the shadow of the Torch enables all sorts of post-lunch resting lines as you gather strength to tackle Live and Let Dyno. We tend to do them unprotected, but the horizontal placements are perfect for practicing your LD trad skills. Walk off to regain the lunch slab at based of Live and Let Dyno. Best access to the base of this is from the trail that heads directly to the base of the Torch feature from the north. Anchors on top for belaying. Walk off.
content.protection: Trad, small to medium cams, single rack.
content.location: North side of The Torch, see location map.

content.description: The left vertical crack (farther away from the Torch) on the uppermost east-facing wall. The better of the two vertical cracks with gear ranging from solid horizontal cracks to the prominent, but irregular vertical crack. Rap/lower from anchors. Good trad practice.

climbs.name: Live and Let Dyno
climbs.fa: Arjun Heimsath, Hanna Breetz and Geir Hundal

content.description:
Named after the James Bond, "Live and Let Die".  

  Starts from bottom of the formation at a lovely lunch slab on the north side. Moderate climbing past three bolts and a warm up bulge gains the base of the torch where some careful moves past two more bolts and loose to rotten rock are needed to get up and traverse under the roof. Clip the bolt protecting the roof, clear the roof and pass two more bolts to anchors. Rap or lower the line.

 This was the first line that attracted AMH to the torch. I scoped it thoroughly on the first day while trying to find a way up the Torch, and decided not to try while rope soloing. HLB worked it with me cleaning over a couple weekends and Geir helped me better establish the line and decide where to put the bolts. Just as well I didnt try soloing it as the rock took a lot of cleaning and the crux moves to clear the roof are some of the hardest in the area. Is still not entirely clean and needs a bit more work.

This was what we considered to be the most straightforward way to get to the top of this iconic feature. We HAD to get to the top! The initial attempt led to AMH about 5 feet above a tiny cam in a horizontal and facing the crux that looked tricky and loose. That led to a bit of down climbing and the placement of the single bolt to make the move onto the arete a bit more secure.  

  Start on the south-east facing side on ledge that supports the Torch. Climb through the obvious weakness to gain a small ledge. Clip one bolt, move left and up and then back right to the top. Small to medium cams. This was the first ascent to get to the top of the Torch.
content.protection: Single bolt, horizontal placements that will take small to medium cams well. A 0.25, 0.3, 0.4, 0.5, and 0.75 should give you plenty to work with. The FA was on a 0.25 and a 0.75. Metolius chain with rap ring. Better to belay from the top rather than set up a slingshot (then you can both enjoy the gorgeous view!).

content.description: Using the same trail, access similarly narrow buttress as Rest and Digest leading up similarly good quality rock and easy climbing with ample protection. The trick is not to disturb the bees that inhabit the massive nest visible from the west and south on the trail into Shadow Buttresses. Check on them carefully during warm weather, but they seem absent in cooler times!
content.protection: Trad, small to medium cams. Watch the bees!
content.location: Next buttress to the right (west) of Rest and Digest.

content.description: The Torch area describes the torch feature itself and the climbs in the immediate surrounding.
